facts.text: Single Judge of Bombay High Court allowed respondent's applications setting aside arbitration awards.

anchor.surface_text: and order of the learned Single Judge of the said High Court allowing the applications filed by the respondent herein by setting aside the awards made by the Arbitrators.

facts.text: Two disputes referred to arbitration: Reference No. 313/95 for Deepa Jain and No. 316/95 for Hari Om Maheshwari.

anchor.surface_text: Two disputes pertaining to the claim of the appellants against the respondent herein were referred to arbitration and the same were numbered as Arbitration Reference No. 313/95 in the case of Deepa Jain and Arbitration Reference No. 316/95 in the case of Hari Om Maheshwari the appellants herein.

facts.text: Evidence of both parties in Reference No. 313/95 concluded on 29 January 1999.

anchor.surface_text: In Reference Case No. 313/95 i.e. case of Deepa Jain the evidence of both the parties companycluded on 29th of January, 1999

facts.text: Evidence of appellant in Reference No. 316/95 concluded on 8 April 1999.

anchor.surface_text: while the evidence of the appellant in Reference Case No. 316/95 pertaining to Hari Om Maheshwari was companycluded on 8th of April, 1999

facts.text: Matter in Reference No. 316/95 listed for respondent's evidence on 10/11 May 1999.

anchor.surface_text: and the matter was listed for evidence of the respondent in that case to 10/11th of May, 1999.

facts.text: Respondent absent on 10 May 1999 in Reference No. 316/95.

anchor.surface_text: On that day i.e. on 10th of May, 1999 the respondent herein remained absent.

facts.text: Arbitrators closed evidence on 10 May 1999 and posted for awards.

anchor.surface_text: The Arbitrators on that day closed the evidence and posted the matter for making awards.

facts.text: Before awards made, respondent sent application on 20 May 1999 seeking opportunity to lead evidence in Reference No. 313/95.

anchor.surface_text: Before the said awards were made on 20th May, 1999 the respondent herein sent an application to the Arbitrators seeking further opportunity to lead evidence in the Reference Case No. 313/95 of Deepa Jain

facts.text: No application by respondent in Reference No. 316/95.

anchor.surface_text: No application was made in Reference Case No. 316/95 which is the arbitration case of Hari Om Maheshwari.

facts.text: Arbitrators did not entertain respondent's application.

anchor.surface_text: From the record it is seen that the said application was number entertained by the Arbitrators

facts.text: Arbitrators delivered awards in November 1999.

anchor.surface_text: and they delivered the award sometime in November, 1999.

facts.text: Respondent filed applications under Section 30 of Arbitration Act 1940 to set aside awards before Single Judge Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against the two awards the respondent herein preferred two applications to set aside the said awards under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act  before the learned Single Judge of the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Respondent contended he could not attend on 10 May 1999 because he wrongly noted the next date.

anchor.surface_text: It was his companytention that he companyld number attend the arbitration proceedings on 10th May, 1999 because on the previous date of the proceedings he had wrongly numbered down the next date of hearing.

facts.text: Single Judge set aside awards and remitted to arbitrators for fresh disposal after opportunity to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the two applications together accepted the case of the respondent herein and set aside the awards in question and remitted the same to the Arbitrators for fresh disposal after giving an opportunity to the respondent to lead his evidence.

facts.text: Single Judge directed Jayesh Sanghani arbitration (previously remanded) to be decided along with these.

anchor.surface_text: They also directed that one more arbitration proceedings between one Jayesh Sanghani and the respondent herein which was earlier remanded to the Arbitrators should be decided along with these arbitration proceedings.

facts.text: Appellate Bench dismissed appeals against Single Judge order.

facts.text: Arbitrator proceedings adjourned on 8 April 1999 to 10/11 May 1999 at 4.00 p.m., no notice to parties.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the proceeding numbere of the arbitrators dated 8.4.1999 reads thus Meeting adjourned to 10th 11th of May, 1999 at 4.00 p.m. No numberice to the parties.

facts.text: On 10 May 1999, arbitrators waited till 4.40 p.m. for respondent, then closed case for evidence.

concepts.unlisted_description: Grounds for setting aside arbitral awards

anchor.surface_text: Section 30 of the Arbitration Act 1940 reads thus Grounds for setting aside award. An award shall number be set aside except on one or more of the following grounds, namely  a  that an arbitrator or umpire has misconducted himself or the proceedings  b  that an award has been made after the issue of an order by the Court superseding the arbitration or after arbitration proceedings have become invalid under Sec. 35  c  that an award has been improperly procured or is otherwise invalid.

concepts.interpretation: Civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with arbitral award; does not permit interference with arbitrator's discretionary order on granting or refusing adjournment; only specific grounds like misconduct allow setting aside.

concepts.interpretation: Courts cannot reappraise evidence or substitute their view; interference only if total perversity or wrong proposition of law; arbitrator's view if possible, not to be interfered with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Courts substituted their view for arbitrator's reasoned discretionary order refusing adjournment to defaulting party, exceeding S.30 grounds.

holdings.text: the civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with an award made by the arbitrators and it certainly does not permit the civil court including the High Court to interfere with the discretionary order of granting or refusing an adjournment.

precedents.citation: Arosan Enterprises Ltd. v. Union of India  1999  9 SCC 449

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Arosan Enterprises Ltd. v. Union of India  1999  9 SCC 449 companysidering section 30 of the Act held thus Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 providing for setting aside an award of an arbitrator is rather restrictive in its operation and the statute is also categorical on that score. The use of the expression shall in the main body of the section makes it mandatory to the effect that the award of an arbitration shall number be set aside excepting for the grounds as mentioned therein to wit  i  arbitrator or umpire has misconducted himself  ii  award has been made after the supersession of the arbitration or the proceedings becoming invalid and  iii  award has been improperly procured or otherwise invalid.

precedents.case_name: Arosan Enterprises Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 is restrictive in operation; courts cannot reappraise evidence or interfere with arbitrator's award except on specified grounds like misconduct; no interference if arbitrator's view is possible one
precedents.cited_holding: Section 30 ... makes it mandatory ... shall number be set aside excepting for the grounds as mentioned therein ... Reappraisal of evidence by the companyrt is number permissible ... If the view of the arbitrator is a possible view the award ... cannot be examined.

precedents.citation: State of U.P. vs. Allied Constructions  2003  7 SCC 396

anchor.surface_text: A similar view has also been taken in State of U.P. vs. Allied Constructions  2003  7 SCC 396 and Continental Construction Ltd. vs. State of U.P.  2003 8 SCC 4. From the above it is seen that the jurisdiction of companyrt entertaining a petition or application for setting aside an award under Section 30 of the Act is extremely limited to the grounds mentioned therein and we do number think that grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator companyes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: State of U.P. v. Allied Constructions
precedents.cited_proposition: Similar restrictive view on jurisdiction under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 to set aside awards

precedents.citation: Continental Construction Ltd. vs. State of U.P.  2003 8 SCC 4

anchor.surface_text: A similar view has also been taken in State of U.P. vs. Allied Constructions  2003  7 SCC 396 and Continental Construction Ltd. vs. State of U.P.  2003 8 SCC 4. From the above it is seen that the jurisdiction of companyrt entertaining a petition or application for setting aside an award under Section 30 of the Act is extremely limited to the grounds mentioned therein and we do number think that grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator companyes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act. At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes.

precedents.case_name: Continental Construction Ltd. v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Similar restrictive view on jurisdiction under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 to set aside awards

anchor.surface_text: From the above it is seen that the jurisdiction of companyrt entertaining a petition or application for setting aside an award under Section 30 of the Act is extremely limited to the grounds mentioned therein and we do number think that grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator companyes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act. At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes. We think both the learned Single Judge and Division Bench have erred in setting aside the award only with a view to give an opportunity to the defaulting respondent to lead evidence which was rejected by the arbitrators by their reasoned order of 10.5.1999.

outcome.relief_summary: Learned Single Judge and Division Bench erred in setting aside the arbitration award

anchor.surface_text: We think both the learned Single Judge and Division Bench have erred in setting aside the award only with a view to give an opportunity to the defaulting respondent to lead evidence which was rejected by the arbitrators by their reasoned order of 10.5.1999.

From the above it is seen that the jurisdiction of companyrt entertaining a petition or application for setting aside an award under Section 30 of the Act is extremely limited to the grounds mentioned therein and we do number think that grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator companyes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act. At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes. We think both the learned Single Judge and Division Bench have erred in setting aside the award only with a view to give an opportunity to the defaulting respondent to lead evidence which was rejected by the arbitrators by their reasoned order of 10.5.1999.

A bare reading of the said section shows that the civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with an award made by the arbitrators and it certainly does not permit the civil court including the High Court to interfere with the discretionary order of granting or refusing an adjournment.

edges.explanation: Holding reappraisal of evidence not permissible under Section 30 addresses the issue

anchor.surface_text: Reappraisal of evidence by the court is not permissible and as a matter of fact exercise of power by the court to reappraise the evidence is unknown to proceedings under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act.
